newsitem.title: MALAWI: MALAWI CENTRAL BANK CUTS KEY RATE TO 23 PERCENT.
newsitem.headline: MALAWI CENTRAL BANK CUTS KEY RATE TO 23 PERCENT.

text.p: The central Reserve Bank of Malawi on Tuesday announced a four percentage point cut in its lending rate to 23 percent effective from August 1.
Bank governor Matthews Chikaonda told reporters the move was part of the government's policy response to international trading patterns with neighbouring countries.
In the past week the kwacha has depreciated from around 15.4 against the dollar to around 17 kwacha on Tuesday.
Chikaonda dismissed fears that the currency would depreciate further.
"This (the depreciation) is perfectly normal, it is part of the normal functioning of a liberalised market," he said.
He said the bank was aware the currency would depreciate, as it had been under pressure after its regional trading partners had undergone similar experiences.
The kwacha has been hovering around 15 against the dollar for the last two years, but in the last week it fell to a low of 17.70, before recovering a little ground.
Chikaonda said the bank would begin holding back on its foreign reserves and would limit the sale of foreign exchange to commodity dealers if necessary.
"This is a deliberate policy stand to support the economy," he said.
He estimated the government had lost up to $25 million over the past year through currency transactions by "unscrupulous dealers" who had evaded official channels.
In November last year, the bank cut its lending rates by eight percentage points from 35 percent, after a cut in September from 45 percent.
